forecast.rationale: This forecast heavily favors the status quo because German constitutional law makes party bans extremely difficult and time-consuming by design. Historical precedent is crucial here: Germany has only banned two parties since WWII (SRP in 1952, KPD in 1956), and the most recent attempt to ban the far-right NPD took 4 years (2013-2017) before ultimately failing. The Federal Constitutional Court treats party ban cases with extreme caution as they involve fundamental democratic rights. Even if the motion from the 124 MPs has progressed since January 31st, the timeline is prohibitively short. Constitutional court proceedings require extensive evidence gathering, legal arguments, hearings, and deliberation. An accelerated process would be completely unprecedented and would risk appearing politically motivated rather than judicially sound. My forecast is not higher because there is no indication of emergency proceedings or any deviation from normal constitutional processes.
